editorialDecl.p: Don't know who is the Grand Prince Catherine is referring to at the end of the letter.

body.p: Your notification from Yedrovo, dated the 7th, caused me some concern that the feverish attack, as you write, has again afflicted His Highness. However, I think myself that the Yedrovo lodgings, and the people who disturbed him during my journey, are the reason. God grant that this passes. As for your care, I have not the slightest doubt.

It seems to me that His Highness will not reach Moscow in time for my entry, and therefore you need not rush the journey but continue at your pace depending on the paroxysmâ€™s condition. I shall wait until Thursday, but on Friday I will certainly enter the city, because it is absolutely impossible for me to delay further. I remain always well-disposed towards you.

postscript.p: Your sister was with me this morning, and I found no change in her whatsoever. At Mednoe, the chambers of the old woman Shishkova are far better than the palace, and in Tver the Archbishopâ€™s house is very good and made of stone; for this reason I advise you to stop there with the Grand Duke.
